qas.question: What do coins, Federal Reserve Notes and deposits held by despository institutions make up?
What was the monetary base value in 1994?
How much did the monetar base value increase to in 2013?
How many times a year does the Federal Open Market Committee meet?
What would the Federal Reserve buy to try and increase money supply?
What do coins, Federal Reserve Notes, and monetary policy make up?
What was the Treasury Bond value in 1994?
How much did the monetary base value increase to in 1994?
How many times a year does the Federal Reserve Bank meet?
What would the Federal Open Market Committee buy to try and increase money supply?

context: <a0_0><b5_0>The monetary base<b5_0/><a0_0/> consists of coins and Federal Reserve Notes in circulation outside the Federal Reserve Banks and the U.S. Treasury, plus deposits held by depository institutions at Federal Reserve Banks. The adjusted monetary base has increased from approximately <a1_0><b6_0>400 billion dollars<b6_0/><a1_0/> in 1994, to 800 billion in 2005, and <a2_0>over <b7_0>3000 billion<b7_0/><a2_0/> in 2013. The amount of cash in circulation is increased (or decreased) by the actions of the Federal Reserve System. <a3_0><b8_0>Eight<b8_0/><a3_0/> times a year, the 12-person Federal Open Market Committee meet to determine U.S. monetary policy. Every business day, the Federal Reserve System engages in Open market operations to carry out that monetary policy. If the Federal Reserve desires to increase the money supply, it will buy <a4_0><b9_0>securities<b9_0/><a4_0/> (such as U.S. Treasury Bonds) anonymously from banks in exchange for dollars. Conversely, it will sell securities to the banks in exchange for dollars, to take dollars out of circulation.
